importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the lawsuit was filed by Arizona’s attorney general against Speaker Mike Johnson over the refusal to swear in new congresswoman Adelita Grijalva.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Adelita Grijalva won her election in late September 2025, triggering the controversy over her delayed swearing-in.
The timeframe during which the lawsuit was filed and public dispute intensified, culminating in legal action and public statements from both parties.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat congresswoman Adelita Grijalva.
Johnson claims he is following a precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, delaying swearing-in until the House returns from recess after a government shutdown.

The lawsuit argues that the Constitution does not grant the Speaker authority to delay swearing-in of duly elected members and that such a refusal violates constitutional principles of representation.
The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated, aimed at preventing a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthening his position in budget negotiations.
Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson since her election and is attempting to schedule a meeting to resolve the standoff.
The suit seeks a court order allowing a qualified individual to administer the oath of office to Grijalva if Johnson refuses.
The case raises constitutional questions about the role of the Speaker in appointing new members and the rights of elected officials to serve immediately.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly elected Democratic member of Congress from Arizona, who won her seat in late September 2025 and was refused a swearing-in by House Speaker Mike Johnson.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure in the legal and political dispute over the constitutional right to immediate swearing-in of elected officials.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, who refused to administer the oath of office to Adelita Grijalva due to the government shutdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central decision-maker whose refusal to seat Grijalva triggered the legal action and sparked national debate over procedural and constitutional authority.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Attorney General of Arizona, who filed the lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives over the refusal to seat Grijalva.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She represents the state’s interest and argues that the Constitution mandates immediate swearing-in of duly elected members.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, cited by Mike Johnson as precedent for delaying swearing-in after a recess.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her historical precedent is used by Johnson to justify his delay, making her a key reference point in the constitutional debate.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A convicted sex offender whose records are the subject of a petition being used as a political motivation in the delay of Grijalva’s swearing-in.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The delay is alleged to be intended to prevent a vote on releasing Epstein-related records, making it a focal point of political strategy.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body in which the dispute over seating Grijalva is taking place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the institution where the Speaker holds authority over swearing-in procedures and where the constitutional principles are contested.

namedEntities.name: Arizona
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. state whose attorney general filed a legal action to enforce the rights of its elected representative.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The state is asserting its constitutional interest in having its representative serve immediately, highlighting state-level accountability in federal representation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona's attorney general, Kris Mayes, has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Republican Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democratic congresswoman Adelita Grijalva, who won her seat in late September 2025. The lawsuit argues that the Constitution mandates the immediate swearing-in of duly elected members and that Johnson’s delay—based on the precedent of former Speaker Nancy Pelosi—violates constitutional principles and serves as a political maneuver to block a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthen his position in budget negotiations. Johnson claims he will administer the oath when the House returns from recess, dismissing the lawsuit as a publicity stunt. Grijalva, who has not spoken to Johnson since her election, is attempting to schedule a meeting to resolve the conflict. The suit seeks a court order permitting a qualified official to administer the oath if Johnson refuses.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear in Democrats’ New Congresswoman
